Fact Check: Viral video of Japan's lightning-fast electric train is not real

A video of a train ride is being shared on social media along with the claim that the new electric train in Japan is twice as fast as an F-16 fighter aircraft. 

Claim:
This video claims the new electric train in Japan runs at 4,800 km/h. It allegedly completed the 515-km journey from Osaka to Tokyo in just 10 minutes, making it four times faster than an aircraft.

Fact:
This is a time-lapse video of a high-speed bullet train journey from Osaka to Tokyo. The actual journey normally takes 2.5 hours.

Details:
- The video was created by "Fermata Studio", a YouTube channel that makes simulation and time-lapse videos of trains and aircraft.
- The original video was titled "[High-Speed Simulation] Operating Shinkansen Bullet Train, Osaka to Tokyo (515km) in 10 min".
- The YouTuber explicitly stated in the video description: "This movie is a fiction. Normally it takes 2.5 hours from Shin-Osaka to Tokyo. Made by a method called 'Time variant hyper-lapse/time-lapse'."

According to news reports, Japan's fastest bullet trains can reach speeds up to 400 km/h, not 4,800 km/h as claimed in the viral video.

The creator confirmed to AFP Fact Check that the video was intentionally made as a science fiction creation to allow people to experience "extreme speed that is impossible in reality."

Conclusion: The viral video is a fabricated time-lapse simulation, not a real train journey. The speed and travel time claims are completely false.
